summary: This is an FBI communication from the Miami Division to the New York Division, dated September 2, 2010. It summarizes an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager, for attempting to sell victim information. It also requests New York to interview interior designer Robert Couturier regarding his work for Epstein and observations of potential underage girls.

persons.name: Alfredo Rodriguez
persons.role: Previous house manager and butler to Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Subject of an obstruction of justice case for attempting to sell lists of additional Epstein victims to an undercover employee (UCE) for $50,000 after being deposed in civil litigation.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.role: Accused, subject of child prostitution investigation
persons.context: Palm Beach County resident who was the subject of a Miami Division investigation for bringing underage girls to his home for massages and sex acts. He entered a non-prosecution agreement, pled guilty to state offenses, and served prison time and community supervision.

persons.name: Bradley Edwards
persons.context: Deposed Alfredo Rodriguez during the civil discovery process. Rodriguez later contacted him claiming to have lists of additional victims.

persons.name: Robert Couturier
persons.context: Hired by Epstein for remodeling and design services at Epstein's Virgin Islands residence. Reportedly designed a bedroom with pink furnishings and bunk beds appropriate for teenage girls and observed Epstein with an underage girl. May be involved in civil litigation with Epstein.

connections.description: Rodriguez was the previous house manager and butler to Epstein.
Rodriguez was deposed by attorney Edwards, who represented victims in civil litigation against Epstein. Rodriguez later contacted Edwards about undisclosed victim lists.
Couturier was hired by Epstein for remodeling and design services at his Virgin Islands residence. They may be involved in civil litigation against each other.

events.title: Miami Division investigation of Epstein begins
events.description: The FBI's Miami Division begins investigating Jeffrey Epstein for child prostitution.

events.title: Obstruction of justice case opened against Rodriguez
events.description: Miami Division opens an obstruction of justice case against Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager.

events.title: Rodriguez attempts to sell victim information
events.description: Alfredo Rodriguez attempts to sell lists of additional Epstein victims to an undercover employee (UCE) for $50,000.

events.title: Epstein completes community supervision
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein completes his community supervision as a registered sex offender following his state prison sentence.

events.title: FBI requests interview of Robert Couturier
events.description: The FBI Miami Division requests the New York Division to interview interior designer Robert Couturier regarding his work for Epstein and observations of potential underage girls.

keyFacts: Alfredo Rodriguez, Epstein's former house manager, was charged with obstruction of justice for attempting to sell lists of additional Epstein victims to an undercover FBI employee for $50,000 in November 2009.

Interior designer Robert Couturier reportedly designed a bedroom in Epstein's Virgin Islands residence with pink furnishings and bunk beds 'appropriate for teenage girls' and observed Epstein with an underage girl.

Epstein entered a non-prosecution agreement with the U.S. Attorney's Office, pled guilty to state offenses in Florida, served prison time and community supervision, and completed his supervision in July 2010.

The FBI's Miami Division is requesting the New York Division to interview Couturier as part of an ongoing investigation, indicating continued law enforcement interest in Epstein's activities after his conviction.

Epstein's victims filed civil suits against him seeking damages, and the discovery process in that litigation led to Rodriguez's deposition and subsequent criminal attempt to profit from victim information.
